body.p:
It is with a good deal of mortification that I write to you
about a new difficulty that has occurred between me and the congregation.
You know that at the last meeting I was elected for three years at a
salary of eight hundred Dollars. I at once objected to the salary, and so
stated to the committee; and was perfectly satisfied to have the
matter rest for a year at least. Now however, as you will see
by the constitution which I send, there is a law 27, page 23?, which
demands a bond for the faithful performance of the duty of office.
When the thing was first mentioned I at once refused signing
a bond for three years; and asked it as a great favour to let the
matter rest. But the Parnass was urged by some persons, and on
Thursday two weeks ago he put a paper in my hand which contains
as one stipulation that I should stay of three years, and that
the congregation should pay eight hundred Dollars in full, at the
regular quarter day, each under a penalty of $500. He wanted an
answer at once by Friday to lay it before the board on Sunday; of course
the time was too short to consult with you, and I accordingly upon
my own thoughts of what is correct and proper refused to sign for
more than one year, till I were sure that the congregation would not
consent to give my usual salary, upon which by the by no vote was
taken, as the question only occurred on $800, the confusion being so great
that every thing went on rather curiously. At the meeting of the
Board this day two weeks, Mr. Hackenburg proposed to let the
matter rest for one year, but Mrssrs Allen, J. A. Phillips & A. Hart
refused, and it was determined to call a meeting on this day two weeks.
Since then Mr. Gratz, Mr. Israel, Mr. Allen, Mr. Hart and
Mrs Gratz have been urging me to sign the bond, and all acknowledge
that it is unjust to reduce the salary. There are those in the congrega_

tion who would move to let the election aside, in case it were understood I refused accept_
ing the terms. There is a great objection in the minds of my friends to have
Lyons elected, and they say, that it is nevertheless probable that he would
succeed. They appeal to me, whether I would consent to see him unworthy
as him in office, and whether my character would not be subject to
an inadversion? if for the sake of maintaining my own opinion or
even positive declaration, I should refuse acceding to the wishes of my
friends. Further Mr. Gratz just now said that he would bring the
business again before the congregation at their next meeting.
These are all the principal features of the case. My own opinion
is decidedly opposed to my pledging myself to stay with the congregation,
as they have done so much to mortify me; secondly; tis almost
yielding my entire independence; thirdly it is an act of injustice,
and it is certainly not reasonable to exact my ? thereto.
However the whole subject has caused me a great deal of painful
excitement and care and thought. As I said my own opinion is unchanged
which I expressed to Simha the last time we went up to St? Emanuels
of which she can tell you. Yet I now defer to you, and refer the whole
to your judgment, and as you command, so I shall obey. If you think my
opinion right, and that I ought not to yield, I shall refuse; but if you
desire my stay, I shall then sign the paper and send it to Mr
Allen without any further remark.__Answer this therefore
at once as soon as you get it, and put the letter in the post office before
it closes. However think well, and reflect that upon your advice
the happiness or unhappiness of my future life may depend. According
my view of the question I can lose nothing by leaving Philadelphia,
for the congregation who cannot treat me properly after an acquaintance
of 8 years deserve not to have me.
The fourth volume of the Prayer Book is done. The fifth has progressed

as far as the book of Ruth, and I hope we shall see the end of it this
week. I am almost resolved to go and see you, and speak with you
face to face
but it being Hanukah I do not well know how to leave.
But if you wish to see me, I will come on this day week, and return
again on Monday or Tuesday—I acknowledge the receipt of 120 by Mr.
Levy. People from Richd. have not yet paid one cent, thought five
books are now as good as done. Is not this supporting a useful
enterprize? My health is better that it has been, altho' at
nights I sleep very disturbed._ Old Lemon (?)some
time since told me to remember him to you, I forgot to mention it.
Rachel Seixas gave me an embroidered bag aunt I also forgot
to mention this and have had no opportunity for sending. Very likely
it will come with the books.

On Friday and Rosh Hodesh Tibeth? I shall be 31 years
old. She would judge it to be time that now I should be treated
more like a man than a child; but the people I live ?
are unable to avoid higgling and taking the cheapest
goods, altho' of inferior quality. Cheap stores are fashiona_
ble, and cheap minsters of course are better than dear ones—
However that is not the question now; and would to mercy that
nothing like the present had occurred to give me such
a mean opinion of the majority of the congregation I now
have.
My love for all the folks and

If you think proper write by express.
